Amendment No. 1 essentially sets out the opposition's alternative choice model. I want to make a few remarks about it shortly, but before I do that I would like to pursue some issues and raise some questions with the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation that arise from his second reading speech. Firstly, Minister, in your second reading speech you said: The government is continuing to work with industry on the design details of the proposed key features statements. Draft key features statements were prepared in consultation with industry and have been market tested . . . Is it possible for the opposition to get a copy of the proposed draft key features statements and will the government also release the results of the market testing of the key features statements? I make those requests because the information would be helpful in assisting the opposition to further refine its own choice of funds model, and if the results of the market testing are in fact positive I would have thought that the government would be happy to release the information. That is the first query. In your second reading speech you said that the government was not prepared to compromise on the fundamentals of its choice of funds model and that one of those fundamentals was to ensure that employees get a genuine choice as to which fund their superannuation is paid to. Labor is not opposed to that choice fundamental - about employees getting a genuine choice as to where their superannuation money goes. That is precisely why we have proposed our model and are opposing yours, which gives employers the choice of fund rather than employees. My query is: under the government's model does an employer have the right to not accept an employee's nominated superannuation fund? I am interested in your response to that. The third thing I wanted to take up with you is whether an employee who is nominated or who is employed by more than one employer has the right to ask a second employer to pay their superannuation contributions into the fund chosen by the employee as their preferred superannuation fund. If that is the case, does the second employer have the right under the Superannuation Legislation Amendment (Choice of Superannuation Funds) Bill 1998 - under the government's model - to refuse to pay the employee's superannuation contributions into the superannuation fund that the employee has with the first employer? I seek some responses to those questions. While you are thinking about those questions, I would like to follow up a couple of observations made by speakers in the debate on the second reading - the member for Curtin and the member for Parramatta. The member for Curtin said that she could not understand how Labor thought that costs would go up pursuant to the government's choice model. I would direct her to the explanatory memorandum of the bill at page 48 which states that funds will have, from the point of view of employers, initial costs of the order of $21 million and recurrent costs of the order of $15 million and that the funds themselves would have initial costs of the order of $5 million and recurrent costs of the order of $2 million. Given that the government's own explanatory memorandum says that costs will go up, that seems to us to inevitably lead to lower retirement incomes. The explanatory memorandum certainly does not say that costs will come down. The member for Parramatta made a couple of references to Mr Ken Lockery, the principal of Towers Perrin, concerning the issue of choice. I point out to the member for Parramatta that the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation heard from Ken Lockery and before the Senate committee he noted that the majority of employees in large employer based or industry funds would not receive any benefit and might instead suffer an economic loss. He pointed out that the government was ignoring the fact that competitive choice already exists in the superannuation industry at the wholesale market level. He said: The key issue that the government has failed to recognise is the efficiency of our present trustee based system in producing intense competition at the wholesale level between investment managers and between fund administrators. It is clear that many other industry participants support our views. Clearly, the evidence that Mr Lockery put to that Senate committee very much endorses the concerns that the opposition has expressed. (Time expired)

Schedule 1, item 67, page 39 (line 9), omit '1999', substitute '2000'. I will speak briefly in support of the amendments. Included within these amendments are amendments that would extend the start date of choice to 1 July 2000 for both new and existing employees. This amendment is widely supported by both people in the superannuation industry and employers, who are dreading the government's policy of having two separate classes of employees. Having two distinct classes of employees - those employed before 1 July 1999 and those employed after - is entirely inconsistent with the government's argument for wanting to do away with award based superannuation. As we have seen so many times before, the government has an inconsistent position and argument on superannuation. We want to do a favour for the government, employees, employers and superannuation funds by moving amendments which will align the start date for the government's so-called superannuation choice for new and existing employees. We think that the start date ought to be the same, and it ought to be 1 July 2000. The whole superannuation industry has called for this extension of time, including the peak superannuation body, the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia. We also have amendments which revise the definition of `industry based fund'. This amendment replaces the government's definition of industry based fund with a definition which more accurately reflects what a true industry based fund is. This amendment will apply only in the case where, under the government's model, an employer chooses to offer his or her employees the four choice of funds offer - where an employee will have to choose one of four funds. It does that by requiring a fund which seeks to qualify under this definition of an industry based fund to be a not-for-profit fund which operates purely in the best interests of the members of that fund. Amendments in this package relate to the removal of clause 32X, which overrides federal awards. These amendments go to the heart of the entire choice of superannuation debate. The overriding of award based superannuation entitlements, which is what the government is proposing here and in legislation we debated yesterday, is really what the government is all about. The effect of Labor's amendment is to remove 32X from the government's bill, which would otherwise override federal awards. This is hypocritical. Clause 32W says that awards will not be overridden for the purposes of determining notional earnings bases on which to base an employee's superannuation contributions. The reason for this is that, if the award provisions are overridden, em ployers will lose the basis on which to determine an employee's salary for superannuation purposes because that is contained in awards. That means that some employees could choose a fund that would require greater contributions than they are presently receiving. That, in turn, would cost employers more. Surprise, surprise! The government has decided that it wants to do something about this, presumably following lobbying from employer representatives. They say, `We're going to insert a clause which says, 'Well, even though the award no longer applies for superannuation purposes, we'll pretend that it still does just so employers won't be liable to pay any more than they currently are liable to pay.'' We are also moving amendments relating to the default fund option. Because of the complexity of the government's choice of fund model the default fund arrangements are crucial, so we are moving amendments in that area. We are also moving amendments concerning the avoidance of commission based sales under the choice regime. We do not want to see the sorts of things that occurred in places like Chile and, indeed, in the UK. These amendments are designed to try to ensure that that does not happen. We are moving amendments that concern the need for superannuation funds to be year 2000 compliant and, finally, we have an amendment concerning third line forcing provisions - once again, a very important one. If employers are not discouraged from entering into third line forcing arrangements with other parties, the retirement incomes of many Australians will suffer. Having said that in support of the amendments, I hope the House will support them for the benefit of the retirement incomes of thousands of Australian working men and women.

The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: The Department has not undertaken any measures which are categorised as positive discrimination programs. DETYA has been implementing Workplace Diversity, Equal Employment Opportunity (EEO) and Equity measures in line with Government policy and its commitments under the Public Service Act. The Public Service Act requires the department to develop, implement, monitor and evaluate a Workplace Diversity program which incorporates EEO and Equity agendas. The department has been active in meeting this commitment and ensuring that it implements a system that is fair and equitable, and values diversity and non-discriminatory treatment of staff. One of the EEO principles is that judgements are genuinely based on merit. The merit principle aims to ensure people are judged fairly and without bias or favouritism. When offering equal employment opportunities and making decisions based on the merit principle, there are some groups in our society who are unable to gain equal access for a variety of historical and systematic reasons including prejudice, discrimination and unfair treatment. For this reason four EEO groups have been designated. They are women, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, people of non English speaking background and people with disabilities. In accordance with this, DETYA participates in the Australian Public Service wide programs designed by the Public Service and Merit Protection Commission such as the Senior Women In Management (SWIM) Program and the Indigenous Career Development programs such as the Aboriginal Undergraduate Study Awards (AUSA), the Aboriginal Staff Sponsorship Program (ASSP) and Indigenous Cadetships. Strategies designed to assist the designated groups are not designed to give preference to these individuals but rather to remove obstacles preventing them from gaining equal access to employment. The Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question: The Bureau reviewed the state of conservation of Kakadu National Park. It noted that Australian authorities provided additional information on Kakadu. The Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question: This information is not available. Each time a family's entitlement to Childcare Assistance is reassessed Centrelink sends one notification of assessment to that family. This notification details all children in the family using child care as well as detailing the service providers used by those children.

asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 26 November 1998: What is the position of the Australian Government in relation to the detention in Great Britain of General Augusto Pinochet. Does the Government acknowledge that the celebration of the 50th anniversary of the Declaration of Human Rights adds significance to supporting the actions of the British, Spanish and European officials seeking to bring General Pinochet to justice. Is it appropriate for Australia to bring to Chile's attention matters pertaining to the violation of human rights by the Pinochet regime, particularly crimes against humanity and other forms of violation of human rights, as requested by bodies such as Amnesty International. Has the Prime Minister raised with APEC or the Chilean Government matters relating to human rights violations by General Pinochet. Has his attention been drawn to the presence in Australia of former Chileans, many of whom have become Australian citizens, whose family members were killed or disappeared during the Pinochet regime, those responsible remaining free and untried. Will the Australian Government support the case of Manuel Moreno, an Australian citizen originally from Chile, whose son was executed during the Pinochet dictatorship.

The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: The Australian Government recognises that there were many serious human rights abuses in Chile during Senator Pinochet's Presidency. The Government is committed to the protection and promotion of human rights as an integral part of its foreign policy. However, the Australian Government accepts that the issue of whether Senator Pinochet should be extradited to Spain is for the relevant British authorities to decide. Senator Pinochet's rights and obligations will be determined in accordance with existing arrangements under British and Spanish law, taking into account relevant treaty obligations. At the same time, the Government acknowledges that this is a very difficult time for the Government and people of Chile, particularly in the context of Chile's political transition and reconciliation. As citizens of a democratic state they face the challenge of balancing the need for justice with the requirements of reconciliation. The Australian Government's enduring commitment to the principles enshrined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights (UDHR) was recently reaffirmed by the Parliamentary motion moved by the Prime Minister and passed by the House of Representatives on 10 December 1998 to mark the 50th Anniversary of the UDHR. However, as stated above, the Australian Government accepts that the issue of whether Senator Pinochet should be extradited to Spain is for the relevant British authorities to decide. The Government therefore believes that it would be inappropriate to comment on these legal proceedings. As stated above, the Australian Government is committed to the promotion and protection of human rights. However, the Australian Government also recognises the sovereign right of the Chilean people and Government to determine the most appropriate means of delivering and consolidating a transition to full democracy. The Australian Government does not believe that it would be appropriate or helpful to comment on the means chosen by Chile to attain this goal. Advice from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet is that the Prime Minister has not raised with APEC or the Chilean Government matters relating to human rights violations by Senator Pinochet. and (6) The Australian Government recognises that serious violations of human rights occurred during Senator Pinochet's Presidency and acknowledges that many Chilean Australians suffered under his regime. In relation to the specific case mentioned, I would be grateful for more information before providing a response.

asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 1 December 1998: Has the Government raised the maximum weight limit of semitrailers from 42.5 to 45.5 tonnes; if so, will the Government compensate councils who need to upgrade their bridges as a result; if not, why not.

The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: The Government has not raised the maximum weight of semitrailers from 42.5 to 45.5 tonnes. There is a proposal from the National Road Transport Commission to increase mass limits for heavy vehicles fitted with road friendly suspension under which the mass limit for a six axle semitrailer would increase from 42.5 to 45.5 tonnes. The proposal is being supported by the Government because of the productivity improvements it will mean for the road transport industry which will benefit the broader community. One of the issues that is being considered by Commonwealth, State and Territory Transport Ministers is funding for the bridge upgrading required to implement the mass limit increase and the Government has committed to contribute to a bridge upgrading program.

The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: It is methodologically difficult to directly measure the number of persons dependent on 'hard drugs' due to a range of factors including the illegal nature of the activity and the difficulty of gaining access to such hidden populations. A 1997 study conducted for the Australian National Council on AIDS and Related Diseases (ANCARD) Hepatitis C Sub-Committee, estimated that there were 100,000 regular injecting drug users in 1997 with a further 175,000 people injecting drugs on an occasional basis (Hepatitis C Virus Projections Working Group, `Estimates and Projections of the Hepatitis C Virus Epidemic in Australia', August 1998). For the purposes of this study, a 'regular' injecting drug user was someone who had injected for at least 12 months, an average of 10 times per month, with injecting in most months. Heroin and amphetamines (or a combination of the two) were given as the drugs most commonly injected. Funding is currently being provided by my Department to the National Drug and Alcohol Research Centre to revise the estimate of the number of dependent heroin users in Australia. An updated estimate is due at the end of the 1999 calendar year. I would be happy to provide the honourable member with the details when they become available The estimate of 100,000 regular injecting drug users in 1997 represented 0.3% of the total population in that year.

asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 9 December 1998: What requirements exist for the new owners of privatised airports to (a) observe competition policy practices, such as competitive tendering for the use of retail space, and (b) avoid monopoly pricing practices on the lease of retail space. Are the requirements referred to in part (1) being met by the new owner of Canberra Airport.

The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (a) and (b) Overall, retail tenants of the privatised airports are afforded the same trade practices protection available to off-airport businesses. This protection is provided for through Commonwealth legislation such as the Trade Practices Act 1974 and applicable State or Territory Legislation governing commercial trading (these laws apply at leased airports). In the case of Canberra Airport, retail tenants are afforded the protection of the ACT Tenancy Tribunal Act 1994 and the Commercial and Retail leases Code of Practice made under that Act. Canberra International Airport Pty Ltd advise that the terms of the leases (including rent provisions) held by the two retail tenants at Canberra Airport have not changed since the airport was privatised in May 1998.
